message.content: This question requires an understanding of how scientists determine whether previously known planets are still considered planets. Scientists determine whether a planet is still considered a planet based on whether it completes rotations around the sun, meaning it orbits the sun. Scientists determine whether previously known planets are still considered planets based on whether they complete rotations. One of the criteria for classifying a celestial body as a planet is that it must orbit around a star and have enough mass to be in hydrostatic equilibrium (meaning it's nearly round). Additionally, a planet must have cleared its orbit of any other debris. If a celestial body meets these criteria and completes rotations, it is still considered a planet.
